dimensionName: People Development vs. Business Results

statementA.text: When under performance pressure, I focus on achieving business results even if it means delaying some team development activities I had committed to.

statementB.text: In high-pressure periods, I believe team development activities should remain a priority, even if it means results might take slightly longer to achieve.

dimensionName: Innovation vs. Stability

statementA.text: When new ideas challenge the current way of working, I encourage experimentation even when it risks unsettling a well-functioning system.

statementB.text: I prefer to protect well-functioning systems from disruption, even if it means we pass up on experimenting with new ideas.

dimensionName: Transparency vs. Discretion

statementA.text: I believe in sharing difficult organizational news with my team early, even if it risks creating anxiety before I have all the answers.

statementB.text: I believe it’s best to shield my team from difficult organizational news until I have clear solutions, even if it means they feel left out of the loop.

dimensionName: Delegation vs. Direct Control

statementA.text: When a critical task arises, I prefer to delegate even if it means accepting outcomes that may not match my personal standards.

statementB.text: I prefer to retain direct control over critical tasks, even if it means stretching my own bandwidth.

dimensionName: Short-term Wins vs. Long-term Vision

statementA.text: I sometimes pursue short-term wins to build momentum, even if it means deviating from long-term strategic plans temporarily.

statementB.text: I prefer sticking to long-term strategic plans, even if it means short-term wins take longer to materialize.

dimensionName: Speed of Execution vs. Thoughtful Planning

statementA.text: In fast-moving situations, I prefer to act quickly, even if that means planning happens along the way.

statementB.text: I prefer to take time for thoughtful planning, even if it means acting slower in fast-moving situations.

dimensionName: Risk-taking vs. Risk Mitigation

statementA.text: I’m willing to take calculated risks to seize opportunities, even when it means exposing the team to potential setbacks.

statementB.text: I prefer to avoid risks that could expose my team to setbacks, even if it means missing some opportunities.

dimensionName: Customer Needs vs. Internal Priorities

statementA.text: I prioritize meeting customer demands, even when it puts a strain on internal priorities or resources.

statementB.text: I focus on protecting internal priorities, even if it means we can’t meet every customer demand.

dimensionName: Inclusiveness in Decisions vs. Decisiveness under Pressure

statementA.text: Even in high-pressure situations, I seek input from my team, knowing it can slow decisions.

statementB.text: In high-pressure situations, I make quick decisions myself, even if it means involving the team less than usual.

dimensionName: Consistency vs. Flexibility in Policies

statementA.text: I prefer to stay consistent with policies, even when individual situations tempt me to make exceptions.

statementB.text: I’m comfortable making exceptions to policies for individual situations, even if it means being less consistent overall.

dimensionName: Cost Efficiency vs. Value Creation Investments

statementA.text: I focus on keeping costs down, even when that means delaying some investments that could create future value.

statementB.text: I prioritize making investments that could create future value, even when that means higher short-term costs.

dimensionName: Empathy for Individuals vs. Fairness to the Group

statementA.text: I sometimes make exceptions for individuals out of empathy, even if it raises fairness concerns for the group.

statementB.text: I stick to what’s fair for the group, even if it means saying no to individual situations that deserve empathy.

dimensionName: Global Standards vs. Local Adaptation

statementA.text: I prefer to stick to global standards, even when local conditions suggest we should adapt.

statementB.text: I prefer to adapt to local conditions, even if it means straying from global standards.

dimensionName: Work-Life Balance for Team vs. Business Demands

statementA.text: I try to protect my team’s work-life balance, even when business demands make that difficult.

statementB.text: I focus on meeting business demands, even when it puts work-life balance pressures on the team.

dimensionName: Data-driven Decisions vs. Gut Feel / Intuition

statementA.text: I rely on data to guide decisions, even when my intuition suggests a different path.

statementB.text: I trust my intuition, even when data points in a different direction.

dimensionName: Process Discipline vs. Creative Freedom

statementA.text: I prefer to stick to processes, even when creative freedom might produce new solutions.

statementB.text: I’m comfortable giving people creative freedom, even if it means less process discipline.

dimensionName: Protecting Reputation vs. Taking Bold Stands

statementA.text: I avoid bold public stands that could risk our reputation, even if I believe strongly in the issue.

statementB.text: I’m willing to take bold public stands, even when they could risk our reputation.

dimensionName: Empowering Others vs. Protecting from Failure

statementA.text: I empower people to take ownership, even when I know it could lead to failures I could have prevented.

statementB.text: I step in to protect people from failure, even if it means they have less ownership.

dimensionName: Maintaining Morale vs. Driving Accountability

statementA.text: I focus on maintaining morale, even when holding people accountable could lower it temporarily.

statementB.text: I focus on holding people accountable, even when it risks lowering morale temporarily.

dimensionName: Sticking to Commitments vs. Adjusting with New Information

statementA.text: I stick to commitments I’ve made, even when new information suggests a change is needed.

statementB.text: I adjust course when new information emerges, even if it means going back on commitments.

dimensionName: Empowering Stars vs. Building the Whole Team

statementA.text: I invest more time developing my top performers, even if it means the rest of the team receives less focus.

statementB.text: Even though my top performers could benefit from more attention, I choose to distribute my focus evenly across the team.

dimensionName: Emotional Authenticity vs. Emotional Control

statementA.text: I show my genuine emotions, even when doing so may create discomfort or uncertainty in the team.

statementB.text: Even when I feel strongly, I choose to control my emotions to maintain stability for the team.

dimensionName: Emotional Authenticity vs. Emotional Control

statementA.text: I express how I truly feel about difficult situations, even when it might unsettle people.

statementB.text: Even when I want to express my real emotions, I hold back so the team feels steady.

dimensionName: Big-picture Thinking vs. Operational Detail Focus

statementA.text: I stay focused on the big picture, even when operational details could use more of my attention.

statementB.text: Even when I know the big picture matters, I find myself drawn into operational details to ensure things run smoothly.

dimensionName: Persistence vs. Knowing When to Pivot

statementA.text: I push through challenges with persistence, even when signals suggest we might need a different approach.

statementB.text: Even when I believe persistence could pay off, I choose to pivot when evidence suggests the current path isn’t working.

dimensionName: Advocating for My Team vs. Aligning with Senior Leadership

statementA.text: I champion my team’s needs, even if it puts me at odds with senior leadership priorities.

statementB.text: Even when my team would benefit from stronger advocacy, I prioritize alignment with senior leadership’s agenda.

dimensionName: Firm Standards vs. Adaptive Expectations

statementA.text: I hold people to firm standards, even when external circumstances make things harder for them.

statementB.text: Even when firm standards could drive higher performance, I adjust my expectations based on the situation.

dimensionName: Driving Change vs. Respecting Legacy

statementA.text: I drive change forward, even when it challenges longstanding traditions that people value.

statementB.text: Even when change could bring improvements, I choose to respect legacy practices that matter to people.

dimensionName: Centralized Direction vs. Shared Leadership

statementA.text: I set the direction clearly myself, even if it limits others’ input into decisions.

statementB.text: Even when I could provide clearer direction, I prefer to co-create decisions with the team.

dimensionName: Being Accessible vs. Protecting Focus Time

statementA.text: I make myself highly accessible, even when it interrupts my focus on strategic priorities.

statementB.text: Even when my team might benefit from more access to me, I protect time for deep, focused work.

dimensionName: Promoting Internal Talent vs. Bringing in External Freshness

statementA.text: I promote internal talent, even when external candidates might bring in fresh ideas.

statementB.text: Even when internal talent is ready, I choose to bring in external candidates who offer new perspectives.

dimensionName: Optimism vs. Realism in Communication

statementA.text: I emphasize optimism in my communication, even when it means softening difficult truths.

statementB.text: Even when optimism could inspire, I choose to speak plainly about the hard realities we face.

dimensionName: Competing Priorities vs. Singular Focus

statementA.text: I balance competing priorities, even when it dilutes the team’s energy across multiple goals.

statementB.text: Even when there are other important needs, I focus the team’s energy on one major goal at a time.

dimensionName: Taking Responsibility vs. Sharing Responsibility

statementA.text: I take personal responsibility for outcomes, even when sharing accountability could be healthier for the team.

statementB.text: Even when I could take charge, I prefer to distribute responsibility broadly across the team.

dimensionName: Being Hands-on vs. Creating Autonomy

statementA.text: I get hands-on with work, even when stepping back would help build team autonomy.

statementB.text: Even when being more hands-on might improve results, I choose to step back and let the team own the work.

dimensionName: Rewarding Loyalty vs. Rewarding Results

statementA.text: I reward loyalty and long-term commitment, even when newer high-performers contribute more.

statementB.text: Even when loyalty matters, I prioritize rewarding those who deliver the strongest results.

dimensionName: Fast Hiring vs. Careful Selection

statementA.text: I hire quickly to fill gaps, even when a more deliberate process could yield a better fit.

statementB.text: Even when speed is needed, I prefer to take my time to ensure we select the right person.

dimensionName: Conflict Avoidance vs. Conflict Engagement

statementA.text: I smooth tensions to keep the peace, even when unresolved issues linger beneath the surface.

statementB.text: Even when harmony is tempting, I choose to surface and engage with underlying conflicts.

dimensionName: Consistency of Communication vs. Tailoring to Audience

statementA.text: I deliver consistent messages, even when adapting might land better with different groups.

statementB.text: Even when consistency would be simpler, I tailor my message for each audience to increase impact.

dimensionName: Encouraging Debate vs. Driving Alignment Quickly

statementA.text: I encourage debate and different views, even when it slows down alignment.

statementB.text: Even when healthy debate could add value, I move quickly to drive team alignment.

dimensionName: Protecting Culture vs. Scaling Rapidly

statementA.text: I protect our team culture carefully, even when it slows down our ability to scale.

statementB.text: Even when protecting culture is important, I prioritize scaling quickly to meet business demands.

dimensionName: Confidence vs. Humility

statementA.text: I trust my capabilities and back myself in tough situations, even when I know I don’t have all the answers.

statementB.text: Even when I believe in my strengths, I make a point of acknowledging my limits and seeking others’ input first.

dimensionName: Ambition vs. Contentment

statementA.text: I constantly look for the next big challenge to stretch myself, even when I could pause to appreciate what I’ve already achieved.

statementB.text: Even though I could chase bigger goals, I allow myself to feel satisfied with the milestones I’ve reached so far.

dimensionName: Risk-taking vs. Caution

statementA.text: I’m willing to take bold steps and embrace uncertainty, even if the potential downside could create setbacks for me.

statementB.text: Even when bold action could lead to big gains, I prefer to stay cautious and protect myself from unnecessary risk.

dimensionName: Analytical Thinking vs. Intuitive Judgment

statementA.text: I rely on logic and data to make my decisions, even when my gut is telling me to act differently.

statementB.text: Even when analysis could provide clearer answers, I’m comfortable going with what feels right in the moment.

dimensionName: Discipline vs. Flexibility

statementA.text: I stick to my routines and plans, even when unexpected opportunities arise that could pull me off track.

statementB.text: Even when discipline would keep me focused, I allow myself to change course when something new or better comes up.

dimensionName: Patience vs. Sense of Urgency

statementA.text: I let things unfold in their own time, even when it means holding back from pushing for faster progress.

statementB.text: Even when patience might serve me well, I often feel the need to act quickly to make things happen.

dimensionName: Self-reliance vs. Seeking Support

statementA.text: I prefer to solve problems on my own, even when asking for help might save time or energy.

statementB.text: Even when I could probably handle things myself, I choose to reach out and involve others for support.

dimensionName: Focus on Strengths vs. Focus on Weaknesses

statementA.text: I concentrate on building what I’m naturally good at, even if it means some of my weaker areas stay underdeveloped.

statementB.text: Even when playing to my strengths would feel easier, I focus my energy on improving where I’m weakest.

dimensionName: Action Orientation vs. Reflection Orientation

statementA.text: I like to get moving on ideas as soon as possible, even if I haven’t fully thought through all the angles.

statementB.text: Even when quick action could create momentum, I prefer to pause and reflect carefully before I start.

dimensionName: Perfectionism vs. Pragmatism

statementA.text: I strive to produce the highest quality work, even when it takes extra time or effort to get there.

statementB.text: Even when perfection might feel satisfying, I choose solutions that are good enough and move us forward efficiently.

dimensionName: Consistency vs. Adaptability of Values

statementA.text: I hold firm to my core values across situations, even when adjusting them might make life easier.

statementB.text: Even when consistency in values would feel clearer, I adjust them to fit the situation or context when needed.

dimensionName: Long-term Vision vs. Short-term Results Drive

statementA.text: I stay focused on the big picture, even if it means that immediate results sometimes take a back seat.

statementB.text: Even when keeping the long-term in mind would help, I focus my energy on delivering quick wins right now.

dimensionName: Curiosity vs. Decisiveness

statementA.text: I keep exploring possibilities and asking questions, even when it delays making final decisions.

statementB.text: Even when curiosity could open up new options, I prefer to make decisions quickly and stick with them.

dimensionName: Resilience vs. Sensitivity to Setbacks

statementA.text: I bounce back quickly when things don’t go my way, even when others might need more time to recover.

statementB.text: Even when resilience could help me move on, I find myself deeply affected by failures or disappointments.

dimensionName: Self-discipline vs. Spontaneity

statementA.text: I prefer to stick to my plans and routines, even when unexpected opportunities tempt me to break from them.

statementB.text: Even when discipline would keep me on track, I sometimes follow my impulses in the moment.

dimensionName: Optimism vs. Realism

statementA.text: I focus on the possibilities in every situation, even when others point out risks or challenges.

statementB.text: Even when optimism could inspire people, I focus on keeping expectations grounded in reality.

dimensionName: Inner Calm vs. Inner Drive

statementA.text: I work to maintain a sense of inner peace, even when I feel pressure to keep pushing myself harder.

statementB.text: Even when calm would help me feel centred, I let my inner drive fuel constant action and progress.

dimensionName: Self-criticism vs. Self-compassion

statementA.text: I hold myself to high standards and question my own performance, even when I’ve done well.

statementB.text: Even when I could be harder on myself, I choose to treat my mistakes with understanding and compassion.

dimensionName: Love of Mastery vs. Love of Variety

statementA.text: I prefer to go deep and master one subject or skill, even when it means missing out on other interests.

statementB.text: Even when mastery could build my expertise, I choose to explore a wide variety of topics and experiences.

dimensionName: Future-focus vs. Present-mindfulness

statementA.text: I’m always thinking about the next step or future goal, even if it distracts me from the present moment.

statementB.text: Even when planning for the future could help, I focus on staying fully present in what I’m doing right now.

dimensionName: Emotional stability vs. Expressiveness

statementA.text: I make a conscious effort to keep my emotions steady in challenging moments, even when I know showing more feeling might help me connect better with others.

statementB.text: Even when staying emotionally steady might maintain calm, I allow myself to express what I truly feel so others can see my genuine reactions.

dimensionName: Processing privately vs. Processing openly

statementA.text: I prefer to work through my emotional reactions internally first, even if sharing them earlier might help my team understand where I stand.

statementB.text: Even when processing my emotions quietly might give me clarity, I tend to share what I’m feeling with others in the moment as things unfold.

dimensionName: Holding composure vs. Releasing tension

statementA.text: I focus on staying composed under pressure, even when letting out my frustration might provide some short-term relief.

statementB.text: Even when composure might project strength, I sometimes let my frustration or tension show so I don’t bottle it up.

dimensionName: Owning mistakes vs. Protecting reputation

statementA.text: When something goes wrong under my watch, I make it a point to take responsibility, even when I know admitting fault could hurt how others see me.

statementB.text: Even when taking responsibility might seem noble, I often feel the need to protect my reputation by sharing accountability or explaining the broader circumstances.

dimensionName: Driving outcomes personally vs. Delegating accountability

statementA.text: I feel deeply accountable for delivering results myself, even when I know trusting others with full ownership could be more scalable.

statementB.text: Even when personally driving outcomes could give me more control, I prefer to assign full accountability to others so they can own the results.

dimensionName: Owning hard decisions vs. Seeking consensus

statementA.text: I’m willing to take full ownership for tough calls, even when I know involving more voices could reduce resistance to the decision.

statementB.text: Even when owning hard decisions might speed things up, I prefer to build consensus so responsibility is shared across the team.

dimensionName: Addressing conflict directly vs. Preserving harmony

statementA.text: I usually choose to address conflicts head-on, even when I know doing so might temporarily disrupt harmony within the team.

statementB.text: Even when addressing conflict directly might resolve issues faster, I prefer to maintain harmony and avoid stirring up tension unnecessarily.

dimensionName: Staying calm during conflict vs. Using emotion to make a point

statementA.text: I work hard to stay calm during heated discussions, even when I know showing more emotion might help others grasp the seriousness of my view.

statementB.text: Even when staying calm might defuse tension, I let some emotion show during conflicts so people truly understand the strength of my perspective.

dimensionName: Prioritising resolution vs. Prioritising relationships

statementA.text: In conflict situations, I focus on resolving the issue efficiently, even when doing so might leave certain relationships feeling strained.

statementB.text: Even when quick resolution might be possible, I focus on protecting relationships first and accept that solutions may take longer.

dimensionName: Shaping decisions vs. Letting others decide freely

statementA.text: I actively try to shape important decisions through persuasion, even when I know it might limit others’ sense of ownership.

statementB.text: Even when trying to influence decisions might lead to better outcomes, I often let others make their choices without pushing my views strongly.

dimensionName: Building buy-in patiently vs. Driving decisions quickly

statementA.text: I take time to build genuine buy-in, even when doing so slows down decision-making and momentum.

statementB.text: Even when building buy-in could strengthen long-term commitment, I prefer to drive decisions forward quickly to keep things moving.

dimensionName: Using logic vs. Appealing to emotion

statementA.text: When I want to persuade others, I rely on logical reasoning, even when I sense that appealing to their emotions might be more effective.

statementB.text: Even when logic might provide a stronger foundation, I sometimes choose to appeal to people’s emotions to make my case more compelling.

dimensionName: Courage to challenge norms vs. Preserving stability

statementA.text: I’m willing to challenge long-standing practices in my organisation, even when I know it might unsettle colleagues who value stability.

statementB.text: Even when challenging norms could drive meaningful change, I prefer to protect the stability that my colleagues and team rely on.

dimensionName: Speaking up to senior leaders vs. Protecting my standing

statementA.text: I voice my concerns to senior leaders when I believe something is wrong, even when doing so could put my position or reputation at risk.

statementB.text: Even when speaking up might highlight an important issue, I choose to protect my standing by keeping my concerns to myself.

dimensionName: Backing bold ideas vs. Minimising risk

statementA.text: I support bold ideas that could drive major progress, even when I know they carry a higher chance of failure.

statementB.text: Even when bold ideas might create breakthroughs, I prefer to minimise risk by supporting safer, proven approaches.

dimensionName: Courage to make unpopular decisions vs. Seeking acceptance

statementA.text: I’m prepared to make decisions that may be unpopular in the short term, even when I know it could affect how people feel about me.

statementB.text: Even when making an unpopular decision might be right for the situation, I lean toward choices that will help me retain people’s support.

dimensionName: Confronting underperformance vs. Avoiding discomfort

statementA.text: I address underperformance directly with team members, even when I know the conversation will be uncomfortable for both of us.

statementB.text: Even when addressing underperformance head-on could help the team, I tend to avoid those difficult conversations to prevent discomfort.

dimensionName: Investing in long-term goals vs. Prioritising short-term wins
category: Being Strategic vs. Living for Today

statementA.text: I consciously focus on advancing long-term goals, even when that means delaying visible wins that could boost morale right now.

statementB.text: Even when long-term goals deserve attention, I prioritise short-term wins that give the team a sense of progress today.

dimensionName: Balancing today’s fires with tomorrow’s plans
category: Being Strategic vs. Living for Today

statementA.text: I make time for strategic planning, even when urgent daily issues are demanding my immediate attention.

statementB.text: Even when strategic planning is important, I focus on resolving today’s pressing issues first so nothing critical falls through the cracks.

dimensionName: Sacrificing immediate comfort for future strength
category: Being Strategic vs. Living for Today

statementA.text: I’m willing to make decisions today that may be uncomfortable, knowing they’ll strengthen the organisation in the future.

statementB.text: Even when tough decisions might help long-term strength, I prefer choices that maintain comfort and stability today.

dimensionName: Building future capabilities vs. Maximising current resources
category: Being Strategic vs. Living for Today

statementA.text: I invest in developing capabilities that will serve us years from now, even if it means stretching current resources thinner.

statementB.text: Even when building future capabilities might be wise, I concentrate on using our current resources where they’re needed most today.

dimensionName: Choosing long-term growth over immediate results
category: Being Strategic vs. Living for Today

statementA.text: I guide my team toward choices that prioritise long-term growth, even when we could achieve faster results by focusing on the short term.

statementB.text: Even when focusing on long-term growth might benefit us later, I choose paths that deliver immediate results the team can see and celebrate.

dimensionName: Acknowledging strengths vs. Avoiding overconfidence

statementA.text: I try to recognise and acknowledge my strengths, even when doing so risks being seen as overconfident by others.

statementB.text: Even when acknowledging my strengths might help me lead with clarity, I downplay them to avoid any hint of overconfidence.

dimensionName: Being self-critical vs. Giving myself grace

statementA.text: I am often self-critical and hard on myself, even when I know showing myself more grace could help me stay energised and focused.

statementB.text: Even when being self-critical might push me to improve, I give myself grace so I can maintain perspective and resilience.

dimensionName: Owning my influence vs. Staying humble

statementA.text: I consciously own the influence I have on people, even when doing so could make me seem less humble.

statementB.text: Even when owning my influence might help me use it more effectively, I downplay it to ensure I stay grounded and humble.

dimensionName: Believing in my vision vs. Questioning my judgement

statementA.text: I believe in my vision and direction, even when doubt creeps in and I question my own judgement.

statementB.text: Even when believing in my vision might strengthen my leadership, I continue to question my judgement to avoid missing critical risks.

dimensionName: Sharing my personal growth journey vs. Guarding my image

statementA.text: I share my personal growth journey openly, even when I know it might expose past weaknesses or mistakes.

statementB.text: Even when sharing my growth story might inspire others, I guard my image to ensure I am seen as consistently strong.

dimensionName: Sticking to priorities vs. Adapting to shifting demands

statementA.text: I stick to my priorities and see them through, even when shifting demands tempt me to change course mid-way.

statementB.text: Even when sticking to my priorities might deliver stronger results, I shift focus when new demands arise so I can stay responsive.

dimensionName: Finishing what I start vs. Leaving room for better opportunities

statementA.text: I make it a point to finish what I start, even when new opportunities emerge that seem more exciting or valuable.

statementB.text: Even when finishing what I start might show consistency, I let go of some commitments to pursue better opportunities as they arise.

dimensionName: Persisting through slow progress vs. Refocusing on faster wins

statementA.text: I stay focused on longer efforts even when progress is slow, knowing that persistence will pay off over time.

statementB.text: Even when persistence might ultimately succeed, I refocus on areas where faster wins are more visible and motivating.

dimensionName: Balancing honesty with diplomacy

statementA.text: I strive to give my boss honest feedback, even when I know it could create discomfort in our relationship.

statementB.text: Even when honesty might improve outcomes, I focus on diplomacy to avoid creating tension with my boss.

dimensionName: Pushing back vs. Aligning quickly

statementA.text: I’m willing to push back on my boss’s decisions when I believe it’s necessary, even if it risks creating friction.

statementB.text: Even when pushing back might help, I prioritise aligning quickly with my boss’s decisions to maintain harmony.

dimensionName: Sharing concerns early vs. Protecting my boss’s confidence

statementA.text: I share emerging concerns with my boss early, even when I know it might make them feel uncertain or exposed.

statementB.text: Even when sharing concerns early might help prevent issues, I protect my boss’s confidence by waiting until I have firmer answers.

dimensionName: Advocating my team’s needs vs. Supporting my boss’s agenda

statementA.text: I advocate for my team’s needs openly, even when doing so could make it harder to fully support my boss’s agenda.

statementB.text: Even when advocating for my team might be the right thing, I focus on supporting my boss’s agenda to strengthen alignment.

dimensionName: Seeking autonomy vs. Valuing guidance

statementA.text: I seek autonomy in my role, even when I know my boss prefers to stay closely involved.

statementB.text: Even when seeking autonomy might help me grow, I welcome my boss’s guidance to show I value their experience.

dimensionName: Promoting diversity vs. Prioritising speed of execution

statementA.text: I actively promote diversity and inclusion in decisions, even when I know it could slow down execution in the short term.

statementB.text: Even when promoting diversity might enrich outcomes, I prioritise speed of execution so we can deliver fast results.

dimensionName: Protecting employee wellbeing vs. Driving hard for results

statementA.text: I work to protect employee wellbeing, even when it means softening ambitious targets or timelines.

statementB.text: Even when protecting employee wellbeing might strengthen culture, I drive hard for results to achieve organisational goals.

dimensionName: Championing sustainability vs. Focusing on immediate gains

statementA.text: I champion sustainability and long-term responsibility, even when it means passing up short-term gains or efficiencies.

statementB.text: Even when championing sustainability might build long-term trust, I focus on immediate gains to deliver fast impact.

dimensionName: Encouraging open debate vs. Maintaining unity

statementA.text: I encourage open debate on difficult topics, even when it risks creating tension or slowing decisions.

statementB.text: Even when encouraging open debate might surface better ideas, I prioritise unity so the team moves forward together.

dimensionName: Upholding fairness vs. Rewarding high performers disproportionately

statementA.text: I work to uphold fairness across my team, even when rewarding high performers disproportionately could drive faster success.

statementB.text: Even when upholding fairness might boost long-term trust, I reward high performers disproportionately so we achieve results faster.

dimensionName: Prioritising learning vs. Staying focused on current performance

statementA.text: I carve out time to prioritise my own learning and development, even when that means stepping back slightly from immediate performance demands.

statementB.text: Even when prioritising my learning might help me grow in the long run, I stay focused on current performance so I can deliver consistent results.

dimensionName: Investing in feedback vs. Protecting self-confidence

statementA.text: I actively seek out feedback that challenges me, even when I know it might temporarily dent my self-confidence.

statementB.text: Even when seeking feedback might help me grow, I protect my self-confidence so I can stay focused and positive.

dimensionName: Exploring new skills vs. Deepening existing expertise

statementA.text: I push myself to explore new skills outside my comfort zone, even when that means I spend less time deepening my existing expertise.

statementB.text: Even when exploring new skills might broaden my capabilities, I focus on deepening my existing expertise so I stay highly competent in my field.

dimensionName: Prioritising team recovery vs. Sustaining high intensity

statementA.text: I actively encourage my team to pause and recover during demanding phases, even when I know it might slow down short-term momentum.

statementB.text: Even when pausing might help the team recover, I sustain high intensity so we keep pace with organisational demands.

dimensionName: Role-modelling work-life balance vs. Staying always available

statementA.text: I try to role-model work-life balance, even when I know being always available might make me seem more committed to senior leaders.

statementB.text: Even when role-modelling balance could encourage healthier habits, I stay always available so I’m seen as fully dedicated.

dimensionName: Flagging burnout risks vs. Protecting team morale

statementA.text: I flag early signs of burnout in my team, even when doing so might dampen morale or create concern among stakeholders.

statementB.text: Even when flagging burnout might help address issues, I protect team morale by keeping concerns low-profile until absolutely necessary.

dimensionName: Focusing on stabilising morale vs. Acting decisively on tough cuts

statementA.text: In a crisis, I focus on stabilising my team’s morale, even when that means delaying tough decisions like job cuts or major restructures.

statementB.text: Even when stabilising morale might ease tensions, I act decisively on tough cuts so we can secure the organisation’s survival.

dimensionName: Communicating openly vs. Managing panic risk

statementA.text: During business crises, I communicate openly and share uncomfortable facts, even when I know it might increase anxiety or panic.

statementB.text: Even when open communication might promote trust, I limit what I share so I can manage panic risk and keep people calm.

dimensionName: Exploring new opportunities vs. Protecting core operations

statementA.text: In times of crisis, I push myself to explore bold new opportunities, even when that means stretching resources thinner than feels comfortable.

statementB.text: Even when exploring new opportunities might help us break through, I protect core operations so we don’t risk what we still have.

dimensionName: Allowing myself space to heal vs. Staying outwardly strong for others

statementA.text: When facing a personal crisis, I allow myself space and time to heal, even when it means I may not appear as strong or dependable to others.

statementB.text: Even when allowing myself space to heal might help me recover better, I stay outwardly strong for others so they feel supported and reassured.

dimensionName: Sharing my situation with colleagues vs. Keeping struggles private

statementA.text: During a personal crisis, I choose to share my situation with close colleagues, even when I know it might make me feel exposed or vulnerable.

statementB.text: Even when sharing my situation might bring support, I keep my struggles private so I can protect my sense of professionalism and boundaries.

dimensionName: Delegating key responsibilities vs. Holding on tightly to control

statementA.text: In personal crises, I delegate key responsibilities, even when it feels uncomfortable to let go of control at critical moments.

statementB.text: Even when delegating might help me manage better, I hold on tightly to control so I can ensure nothing slips during the crisis.

dimensionName: Providing emotional reassurance vs. Pushing hard for performance

statementA.text: When my team is in crisis, I focus on providing emotional reassurance and stability, even when that means easing off immediate performance pressures.

statementB.text: Even when emotional reassurance might help the team feel steadier, I push hard for performance so we don’t fall behind at a critical time.

dimensionName: Involving the team in solutions vs. Making top-down decisions

statementA.text: In a team crisis, I work to involve the team in shaping solutions, even when it means the process takes longer than acting on my own.

statementB.text: Even when involving the team might build buy-in, I make top-down decisions so we can move swiftly and decisively.

dimensionName: Calling out mistakes openly vs. Protecting team cohesion

statementA.text: During a crisis, I call out mistakes openly so we can learn fast, even when I know it might temporarily strain team cohesion.

statementB.text: Even when calling out mistakes might help us improve, I protect team cohesion so we stay united under pressure.

dimensionName: Spending time understanding existing dynamics vs. Driving quick changes
category: When I join a new team

statementA.text: When I join a new team, I spend meaningful time understanding the existing dynamics and culture, even when that means delaying the quick changes I think are needed.

statementB.text: Even when understanding existing dynamics might give me useful insights, I drive quick changes so the team sees early action and direction.

dimensionName: Building personal relationships vs. Establishing authority fast
category: When I join a new team

statementA.text: In my early days with a new team, I prioritise building genuine personal relationships, even when that means my authority might not be immediately visible.

statementB.text: Even when building personal relationships could help long-term trust, I focus on establishing authority fast so expectations are clear from the start.

dimensionName: Observing quietly vs. Making my presence felt
category: When I join a new team

statementA.text: When I join a new team, I choose to observe quietly at first, even when I know making my presence felt might give people faster clarity about my leadership style.

statementB.text: Even when observing quietly might give me a better read on the team, I make my presence felt early so people know what to expect from me.

dimensionName: Letting them find their rhythm vs. Setting clear expectations early
category: When a new team member joins my team

statementA.text: When a new team member joins, I give them the space to find their rhythm and style, even when it means I hold back from setting strong expectations right away.

statementB.text: Even when letting them find their rhythm might help them settle in comfortably, I set clear expectations early so they know exactly what’s required.

dimensionName: Encouraging them to ask questions vs. Expecting them to figure things out
category: When a new team member joins my team

statementA.text: I actively encourage a new team member to ask questions, even when it slows down our immediate momentum or decisions.

statementB.text: Even when encouraging questions might help them learn faster, I expect them to figure things out so they develop independence from the start.

dimensionName: Letting them build relationships naturally vs. Facilitating key connections
category: When a new team member joins my team

statementA.text: I let a new team member build relationships naturally over time, even when I know that proactively facilitating key connections could speed up their integration.

statementB.text: Even when letting them build relationships naturally might help authenticity, I facilitate key connections so they can integrate faster.

dimensionName: Taking time to explore root causes vs. Acting fast on visible issues

statementA.text: When solving a problem, I take time to explore root causes thoroughly, even when that means delaying quick action on what’s immediately visible.

statementB.text: Even when exploring root causes might give deeper insight, I act fast on visible issues so we can show early progress and prevent escalation.

dimensionName: Involving diverse viewpoints vs. Driving towards my own solution

statementA.text: I actively involve diverse viewpoints when tackling tough problems, even when it complicates or slows down the decision-making process.

statementB.text: Even when involving diverse viewpoints might lead to richer ideas, I drive towards my own solution so we can move with clarity and speed.

dimensionName: Experimenting with unconventional approaches vs. Sticking with proven methods

statementA.text: When faced with difficult problems, I’m willing to experiment with unconventional approaches, even when it increases the risk of failure.

statementB.text: Even when experimenting might lead to breakthrough ideas, I stick with proven methods so we limit risk and stay on solid ground.

dimensionName: Pushing through challenges vs. Reassessing when persistence may no longer serve

statementA.text: When I hit major obstacles, I push through and stay committed, even when reassessing the situation might reveal it’s wiser to pivot.

statementB.text: Even when pushing through might showcase resilience, I reassess when persistence may no longer serve so I can redirect my energy strategically.

dimensionName: Sticking with long-term goals vs. Adapting goals when conditions change

statementA.text: I stick with my long-term goals despite setbacks, even when adapting them might seem more practical given changing conditions.

statementB.text: Even when sticking with long-term goals might demonstrate grit, I adapt goals when conditions change so I stay relevant and effective.

dimensionName: Continuing despite personal doubt vs. Pausing to reflect on my inner voice

statementA.text: I keep going despite personal doubt, even when pausing to reflect on my inner voice might help me recalibrate.

statementB.text: Even when continuing despite doubt might show strength, I pause to reflect on my inner voice so I can act with greater clarity.

dimensionName: Prioritising individual customer needs vs. Protecting scalable systems

statementA.text: I prioritise meeting individual customer needs, even when it means creating exceptions that might strain our scalable systems.

statementB.text: Even when prioritising individual customer needs could delight them, I protect scalable systems so we can serve all customers consistently and efficiently.

dimensionName: Customising solutions vs. Encouraging customers to adapt

statementA.text: I’m willing to customise solutions for customers, even when encouraging them to adapt to our standard offerings could make delivery smoother and faster.

statementB.text: Even when customising solutions could strengthen relationships, I encourage customers to adapt so we can maintain speed and consistency in delivery.

dimensionName: Saying yes to ambitious customer demands vs. Managing expectations carefully

statementA.text: I say yes to ambitious customer demands, even when managing expectations more carefully might help prevent over-promising and under-delivering.

statementB.text: Even when saying yes to ambitious customer demands could win short-term goodwill, I manage expectations carefully so we can deliver on what we promise.

dimensionName: Pursuing flawless delivery vs. Prioritising speed over perfection

statementA.text: I pursue flawless delivery in execution, even when prioritising speed over perfection might help us seize short-term opportunities.

statementB.text: Even when pursuing flawless delivery could strengthen our reputation, I prioritise speed over perfection so we can capture opportunities in the moment.

dimensionName: Strictly following plans vs. Adapting on the fly to emerging realities

statementA.text: I stick closely to execution plans we’ve designed, even when adapting on the fly might better address emerging realities or unexpected challenges.

statementB.text: Even when strictly following plans might provide consistency, I adapt on the fly so we can stay aligned with shifting ground realities.

dimensionName: Focusing on cross-functional alignment vs. Prioritising quick wins within my scope

statementA.text: I focus on cross-functional alignment to ensure seamless execution, even when prioritising quick wins within my own scope could show faster results.

statementB.text: Even when focusing on cross-functional alignment might help long-term execution, I prioritise quick wins within my scope so we can build early momentum.

dimensionName: Setting exceptionally high standards vs. Prioritising team morale during tough phases

statementA.text: I set exceptionally high standards for my team, even when prioritising morale during tough phases might make people feel more supported.

statementB.text: Even when setting exceptionally high standards could push the team to greatness, I prioritise morale during tough phases so people stay motivated and resilient.

dimensionName: Encouraging internal competition vs. Focusing on collective collaboration

statementA.text: I encourage a healthy level of internal competition to fuel high performance, even when focusing on collective collaboration might create smoother dynamics.

statementB.text: Even when encouraging internal competition might drive sharper performance, I focus on collective collaboration so we grow together as one unit.

dimensionName: Rewarding star performers vs. Ensuring even contributors feel equally valued

statementA.text: I actively reward star performers, even when ensuring even contributors feel equally valued might build broader team loyalty.

statementB.text: Even when rewarding star performers could incentivise excellence, I ensure even contributors feel equally valued so no one feels left behind.

dimensionName: Seeing Yourself in Others

statementA.text: I consciously try to recognise parts of my own strengths and struggles in my team members, even when it means I must confront qualities in them that I haven’t fully accepted in myself.

statementB.text: Rather than seeing reflections of myself in my team, I focus on understanding them as distinct individuals, even if it means missing shared patterns that could help me connect with them more deeply.

dimensionName: Seeing Yourself in Others

statementA.text: I often spot my younger self in colleagues’ mistakes and ambitions, and I balance guiding them with allowing them to learn their own lessons even when my instinct is to protect them from what I once experienced.

statementB.text: Rather than interpreting my team’s actions through the lens of my own past, I prefer to observe and respond to their choices as they unfold, even when that means I might miss opportunities to mentor through shared experience.

dimensionName: Pushing Teams to Become Like You
category: Pushing Teams to Become Like You

statementA.text: I consciously encourage my team to adopt my working style and decision-making approach, because I believe it drives results even though I know it may limit their opportunity to develop their own unique strengths.

statementB.text: Rather than shaping my team in my own image, I actively encourage them to find their own ways of working and deciding, even if it means results come more slowly or in unexpected forms.

dimensionName: Pushing Teams to Become Like You
category: Pushing Teams to Become Like You

statementA.text: I often set my personal standards as the blueprint for how the team should operate, because I want to maintain consistency even if that reduces diversity of thought and innovation.

statementB.text: Instead of expecting my team to mirror my standards or style, I focus on enabling them to set their own benchmarks, even if that means navigating more complexity and inconsistency.

dimensionName: Empathy

statementA.text: When my team members struggle, I make it a point to truly feel what they are going through and offer emotional support, even though I sometimes worry this could soften the edge I need to drive hard results.

statementB.text: Rather than deeply engaging with my team’s emotions, I focus on keeping a certain distance to stay objective and decisive, even though it might make me seem less approachable in their times of need.

dimensionName: Empathy

statementA.text: I often adjust my expectations and timelines when I sense that someone on my team is overwhelmed, because I believe people matter more than deadlines even though it can create delivery pressures elsewhere.

statementB.text: Rather than modifying timelines or expectations based on how my team is feeling, I hold steady to our commitments, even if that means I’m perceived as less sensitive to individual stress.

dimensionName: The Visionary

statementA.text: I often find myself speaking about what lies ahead, painting futures that others can’t yet see, even when I know the path there is still unclear and fragile.

statementB.text: I usually stay grounded in the realities of today, holding back bold possibilities until I can see a feasible path that others can reliably follow.

dimensionName: The Strategist

statementA.text: I feel most effective when I map out the terrain before I move, crafting structured responses even in chaos, knowing that my plans might be reshaped by events I can’t control.

statementB.text: I prefer to dive into problems without too much architecture, trusting that flexibility and sharp instincts will guide me more effectively than a rigid, pre-set blueprint.

dimensionName: The Operator

statementA.text: I often track, measure, and refine the small moving pieces, believing that consistent control of execution is what builds credibility - even if it means missing the bigger conversation.

statementB.text: I prefer to let the details flow organically, focusing instead on direction and influence, even if that means some operational loose ends might occasionally fray.

dimensionName: The Builder

statementA.text: I think long term, shaping systems that will outlast me - even when the pace is slow, or the outcome may not reflect my name directly.

statementB.text: I lean toward quick wins and visible results, believing the present impact matters more than building structures that others might benefit from when I’m gone.

dimensionName: The Innovator

statementA.text: I get restless with sameness and stability, often compelled to reinvent - even when others around me haven’t asked for change or feel unprepared to absorb it.

statementB.text: I’m more at peace refining proven approaches, favouring reliability over novelty, even if it means I might miss chances to spark fresh breakthroughs.

dimensionName: The Coach

statementA.text: I often spend extra time growing others, even when business urgency says I shouldn’t, trusting that people development is still the highest-return investment in the long run.

statementB.text: I usually focus on delivering outcomes first, believing that people grow best when pushed to meet real demands, rather than being shielded and nurtured continuously.

dimensionName: The Connector

statementA.text: I instinctively introduce people, ideas, or tools from different worlds, trusting that value will emerge from cross-pollination - even when others might not see the link immediately.

statementB.text: I prefer to keep circles focused and closed, trusting in proven networks and familiar methods, even if I occasionally miss unexpected combinations or synergies.

dimensionName: The Challenger

statementA.text: I often speak up when things feel off - even if the room isn’t ready, or harmony is lost - because I believe uncomfortable questions drive better outcomes.

statementB.text: I tend to hold back dissenting views when tension seems unproductive, believing that timing, tact, and group cohesion often matter more than always challenging the status quo.

dimensionName: The Diplomat

statementA.text: I’m naturally drawn to smoothing friction and creating shared space, often choosing unity over speed - even if it delays necessary decisions.

statementB.text: I move quickly through tough calls, even if some feel unheard or bruised - believing leadership sometimes requires sacrificing total inclusion for timely clarity.

dimensionName: The Guardian

statementA.text: I feel a deep duty to protect people, values, and integrity - even if that makes me resist changes that feel risky, fast, or loosely defined.

statementB.text: I’m more inclined to adapt or adjust what once mattered, believing that clinging to past values can sometimes block essential progress.

dimensionName: The Catalyst

statementA.text: I naturally light fires under stagnant systems, believing momentum is better than perfection - even if the disruption causes temporary discomfort or backlash.

statementB.text: I prefer to let shifts evolve organically, waiting for readiness to emerge, even if the system feels too slow or complacent at times.

dimensionName: The Servant

statementA.text: I often hold back my own agenda to support others’ needs and growth - even when it means I stay in the background or miss recognition.

statementB.text: I tend to prioritise my path and responsibilities, trusting that others are capable of managing themselves without needing ongoing personal support.

dimensionName: The Disruptor

statementA.text: I feel most alive when shaking up what’s accepted, poking holes in traditions - even when it unsettles those around me or threatens familiar success.

statementB.text: I often preserve existing ways of working, believing that disruption is sometimes a distraction, and that deep improvement comes from subtle, sustained shifts.

dimensionName: The Pioneer

statementA.text: I gravitate toward uncharted spaces, even without clear maps - trusting that the experience of exploration matters more than the guarantee of arriving.

statementB.text: I prefer well-worn roads with known markers, believing it’s wiser to follow dependable paths than to chase the romance of the unknown.

dimensionName: The Integrator

statementA.text: I instinctively synthesise diverse views into shared frameworks - even if it takes more time - because I believe coherence beats speed.

statementB.text: I push decisions through quickly by focusing on dominant perspectives, believing that consensus can sometimes dilute clarity and momentum.

dimensionName: The Architect

statementA.text: I tend to design mental models and frameworks that help others orient themselves - even if it means I spend more time explaining than doing.

statementB.text: I prefer moving straight to action without over-structuring, believing that frameworks can sometimes overcomplicate what should be intuitive or emergent.

dimensionName: The Storyteller

statementA.text: I often translate complexity into metaphor or narrative, believing people act when they feel the meaning - even if the facts alone would have sufficed.

statementB.text: I favour straightforward data and directness, believing that stories can sometimes cloud urgency or distort what actually matters most.

dimensionName: The Reformer

statementA.text: I notice what’s outdated and broken, constantly seeking to correct - even when others are content or resistant to yet another upgrade.

statementB.text: I often leave things as they are, believing that too much improvement can disrupt what people have grown to trust and rely on.

dimensionName: The Protector

statementA.text: I often step in to shield teams from harm or overload - even if it risks slowing down delivery or disappointing higher-ups.

statementB.text: I hold my teams accountable even under pressure, believing that learning and resilience are forged by facing real consequences and demands.

dimensionName: The Rainmaker

statementA.text: I thrive in securing the next win, client, or opportunity - focusing on external growth even if internal systems lag behind.

statementB.text: I prefer to stabilise internal structures before seeking new business, believing that expansion without readiness is a recipe for collapse.
